title: Specialized LM8UU Bearing for printing with all nozzle diameters

description.text:
Other LM8UU bearings are modeled without much thought put into how the part will be printed.

I modeled each of these to be printed with a their corresponding nozzle size using no infill, no top and bottom layers, and a wall line count of 1.

I would suggest using a persist z-seam for consistancy.

Because of the precise dimensions, this piece will print very quickly. I print the .04mm nozzle size in 13 minutes at .24mm layer height and 25mm/s (only outer wall speed matters here).

If you have a .2mm or .3mm nozzle, use the file meant for the .6mm nozzle. The wall thickness for those would be too delicate.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.24mm

comments.text: These parts are dimensionally accurate, so fitment is going to depend on your machine and the die swell of your filament.
comments.author: TarmacFFS

title: Forstner Bit Cases, Eurohinge and 2 inch

description.text: For many years I have used a piece of wood with a hole partially drilled as my holder for a Forstner bit. It worked but the bits were liable to fall out in my crowded tool boxes and cabinets. I was in the garage the other day looking for something and decided my two Forster bits needed custom cases with threaded tops and bottoms so I made them. After several prototypes I settled on the designs I am uploading.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Medium, 0.2mm layer height

Infill:

20%, 3 wall layers

Notes:

I print these in PLA with the closed sides down. After printing remove the minimal support that is auto generated from the threads and the edges of the cases. The angles are 45 degrees, so you could probably print without support material as what is added is minimal.

Measure, check measurements, create case, add threads, add clearance, test and mod if needed.

I used ANSYS Spaceclaim Engineer. It works like Solidworks.

I did what is in the description. made threads with 5mm pitch and made the grooves slightly larger so they would not bind. I also gave decent clearance between the outside of the male cylinder and the inside of the female cylinder. I added some bumps on once surface to tighten things up if the two pieces bottomed out.

I started out with a hex shape for the top and bottom cases and moved to cases with more bumps so it was not so obvious when they did not lined up with each other based on your tightening.

This is the original design. It is nice an simple but you have to be careful about tightening the two case pieces to line them up. I considered adding stops to keep it from over rotating past having the corners aligned but decided that was not needed. This is the final design with multiple "bumps" to make the pieces more knob like. I also made the bottoms thicker to have more to grab onto when opening if they are tight. Since the threads are intentionally loose to make it easy to open and close, I added three bumps on the smaller one and multiple bumps on the larger one. Their purpose is to wedge the threads against each other and hold the pieces tight. The left case is for the 2 inch bit and the right case is for the euro hinge bit. The B threads are slightly looser than the A threads and it is noticeable when opening or closing. I also did the center recesses fro the center tip of the bit different. No reason for that.

author: whgold

description.text:
(see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2699619 for a Taz 6 version)
I just created this dial gauge adapter for leveling the Z axis (X carriage guides) on Taz 3-5 machines.
Makes it a lot easier. I had been using a digital caliper, but it was not very accurate and I was never sure if it was plumb, etc.
This one clips over the top guide rail, and swings onto the lower rail. There is a small hole for a 1/16" (1.5mm) pin, but you probably won't need to use it. The bottom clip curves and tightens as it engages the rod.
Use 1/4-20 x 1" or M6 hardware to fasten the dial gauge to the adapter. Make sure to use washers to avoid crushing and loosening, and tighten so it will not move around in use.
I used a 1/4-20 x 1" hex cap screw, a flat washer, lock washer and nut.
This setup makes it easy to correct bed leveling and the Z/X axis transport misalignment.
Set your nozzle height to about 5-10mm above the bed. Turn off the power so you can turn the Z axis screws by hand to level the X carriage.
Turn the power back on and move around the bed to adjust the bed corner screws.
This helps even if you are using auto leveling.
Happy printing!

author: whgold

description.text:
ESP32 E-Ink Developement Board

https://github.com/mike-rankin/ESP_trINKet

This design was an experiment using an E-Ink display. It can be powered off of a battery or USB cable. If a battery and USB cable are pluggin it together then it will charge the battery.

This latest board revision has a number of ESP32 pins swapped around making it compatable with the gxEPD library.

The programmer board is located at: https://github.com/mike-rankin/ESP32_Programmer

Special thanks to: Drew at OSH Park for supplying the PCB and Jean-Marc Zingg for the library. The project started out using the Waveshare library that was difficult to use. The gxEPD library is much better.

The Sleep test code right now does a hardware test verifying the display, sensors and ESP32 are functional are functional. If you manage to create something of your own I would love to see it by reaching me at @mikerankin

title: Brandub Board Game

description.text:
"Brandub is a Celtic board game, based on pieces and playing boards found in runs and digs in Ireland and Wales. The game itself is a fast, enjoyable tactical challenge that leaves you wanting to play again and again. Simple rules but engagingly complex play for all skill levels."

Addendum: Brandub is one of the oldest known 2-player games that falls into the genre of "unequal forces" games. While 1 player is given 8 pieces (called "Barons"), the other player is given 5 pieces (4 "princes" and 1 "king"). The different pieces have different abilities, perhaps the most notable being the fact that the king cannot be removed from play by any means.

I present you my Maxxter HDMI Switch brackets. These brackets allow you to attach your HDMI switch underneath any surface of your TV table to have it not lay or fly around in your TV setup.

The bracket can be used with or without screw holes, allowing you to either screw or gluing it under a surface. The glue option is only recommended if you don't want to screw any screw into your TV table or you own a TV table that won't allow you to drill holes into it.
The device must be placed into the brackets upside down due to it's unusual shape (It's getting a tiny bit wider at the bottom).
However if you print the brackets 2% larger, so scale it up to 102%, you may find that you can put the device into the brackets facing up like normal.

The brackets had been modeled quickly and do work nicely.

Here is a info page of the device I'm actually talking about:

title: Rasberry Pi Retropie old School controler box

description.text:
Retropie controller box for use with the Raspberry pi.

UPDATE;

Added files for a 3 part case, two lower sections and the same upper top plate

I wanted this to be a stand alone controller so i did not house the Raspberry pie inside the box. It looks like it is possible that it may fit but there are no cutouts for it.

Everything is put together with m3 bolts and nuts.

I have made slight modifications to the design from what is shown, nothing that will be noticed just a few tweaks to get everything to fit better than my prototype.

One of the button nuts will not be used due to being too close to bolt standoff, i made the cut-outs slightly smaller so buttons on the side will actually screw into the case.

Buttons and joystick can be found here

description.text: This is just a quick design that I sketched out. Hope you like! you will probably need to change the size.

I was tired of constantly moving my Diet Coke around my desk and forgetting where I put it as I worked on projects, so I made this handy Can Holder that clips to the edge of my desk. It's specifically designed for the dimensions of my workbench, so that the bottom clips into the support member that runs along the front of the desk.

The clip consists of two pieces - a hook and arm, which both attaches to the desk and supports the weight of the can; and a ring, which prevents the can from tipping off. There are small taps projecting from the ring, which lock into slots in the arm to secure the ring in place without adhesive.

Works with 12 oz. bottles as well.

Pen holder for a home/hobby CNC. This thing is designed to be used with two 1/4-20 bolts. One screws in from the flat side and is chucked into the router's 1/4" collet. The other is used to lock in the pen or pencil. Neither of the holes are designed with threads inside. I printed at 60% infill so it wouldn't flex while drawing and there would be plenty of material for the bolts to cut threads into.

Set the pen so it looks like the tip is in line with the spindle center. Lower the Z axis until the tip touches a piece of paper. Rotate the spindle/collet 360 degrees. If the pen draws a circle, it needs to be adjusted. If it stays in one spot and just makes a dot, you have it set correctly.

The pen slot is sized based on a standard Sharpie Permanent Marker, with about an extra millimeter of radius for slightly larger pens. The side opposite the set screw is tapered to a point to accept smaller diameter pens too.

remixed_from.title: Creality Ender-4 3D printer LCD Screen Frame

title: Creality Ender-4 External Tilted LCD Screen Frame

description.text:
ThinhTran made an excellent screen frame for the Ender 4 that tilts the frame back 30 degrees so you don't have to bend down to read the screen . . . but . . . I'm planning on using the frame to build a build chamber to better work with the more sensitive filaments, and this frame insets the screen into the frame.

I wanted a frame tilted out 30 degrees, not back 30 degrees . . .

So I took Thinh's excellent design, copied the bolt positions and tossed the rest. I then designed the frame in the shape I like and now we have an alternative to an already great option.

Printer:

Creality Ender 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2-0.25

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Designed to print with the face flat. The SD card notch will need supports, but the bottom tab may do without support -- your call.

I made my draft print (and the final print -- close enough) at 0.3mm/layer, but the thick layer height didn't give good layer cohesion on the thin wall on the left. 0.25mm/layer should be enough. That wall is pretty thin, so if any reports of trouble, I'll bump the thickness up.

Carefully remove supports, particularly around the SD card slot -- the supports may be stronger than that wall.

Everything should swap from the stock frame (bolt->frame->spacer->board->nut).

If you opt to mount the screen on the right face of the frame (turning the whole frame 90 degrees) the cables will be tight, but should fit. the tilt will also make the SD slot much easier to get to.

comments.text: Printing with ABS plastic and then dipping it in Acetone makes it really watertight... i wanted a pelletizer that was clean and was made as much on the printer as possible and durable and easy to locate parts to make that i think that every body has in their junk boxes

i tried to find bearings for this but none that would work so this is as durable as i can make using plastic

the grub screws seem pretty large for this but are necessary as you will see when you put this together when cutting it puts a lot of pressure on the drill bit causing a real big kick back so it is imperative to have the grub screws these do 2 things it keeps the drill from crushing the sleeve and wabiling and second it keeps the ware on the largest part of the sleve

i put this between my legs while sitting so there is no nead for a clamp down i have considered making a clamp down as well as hand held filament feed or drive directly from the drill but the way that it is know is pretty fast and with the inner ptfe tube this holds the filament while feeding so you can feed a whole role realy fast

print all parts using PLA not ABS
PLA is a much harder than ABS ,ABS wares to fast

the theory of this is that 2 serfices the hardest material will ware the softest material so all ware serfices are the same material for no ware if you have ever tried to file down PLA you know how hard this stuff is

print everything at 60% infill 100% would be better
every thing is threaded for m6 threads but the sleeve for some reason will not print the threads properly for a tight fit if you print this part at the lowest heigth of .1 i think that the threads might be tight enough
threaded for

parts neaded
1-7/16" drill bit
4-m6x6 grub screws
or for a tighter fit coarse
4- 1/4-20 x 1/4"
1-m6x30 3d printer tube and nut there is 20mm threaded part so any thing larger than 20mm
4-plastic screws or screws of your choice for the hold down ring
1-wide mouth mason jar and ring

So, I make all of my mice's habitats myself using bins. The bin cages are great but the one huge headache with them is attaching a water bottle. With the lip around the lid, it's hard to get the bottles to sit at the correct angle for the critters to easily get a drink.

This is a really simple device to attach to the side of the cage. It holds the bottle out away from the lip so it stands upright, which is how to get the water to flow into the tip of the nozzle. The nozzle itself goes through a hole in the bin.

I hope I got the measurements right! Basically all I need to do is drill holes corresponding to the holes in the base and attach the device (you could use bolts but I'm just gonna use pipe cleaners, it's easier and cheaper). Then the bottle can slide into the ring. I'll update this when I get the printer and make one, and let you know if it works! If you make one I hope you show me. :) Depending on the size of your bottle you might have to adjust the diameter of the ring.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8NkEDX63xAx
Just a mermaid tail wine stopper the wife requested. Best if printed in flex

UPDATE 12/14/2017 original upload was too small for hard drives. Fixed now

title: da Vinci Bar, Construction Sticks, Dome, Bridge, Math

description.text:
da Vinci Bars/Sticks for architectural or mathematical constructions. 80mm or 100mm by 6 mm by 6mm with 7 symmetrical notches.

They can be used for children to experiment with da Vinci domes or bridges, which could be as frustrating as eye-opening! Simple as they are, these sticks can be used to explore a variety of mathematical ideas. At times, team work is helpful or even required. As always, print a bunch and allow children to teach us adults how to make use of them. Or better yet, play with them!

References:

  1. http://www.instructables.com/id/Da-Vinci-Popsicle-Stick-Bridge/

  2. http://archive.bridgesmathart.org/2003/bridges2003-229.pdf

author: h4rr21

print_settings.Notes:: A high infill is important on the frame side adapter, at least for PLA. Otherwise you might overtorque the securing screw and crack the adapter.

title: HyperCube Evolution Gantry Cable Chain Holder

description.text:
This is an attachment to easily add a 20x15mm cable drag chain to the X gantry of most HyperCube Evolution extruder mounts, so you can keep all the hotend wires nice and neat. It will work with any extruder mount that is similar to Scott3D's original mount (with a tall 'tail' that the part cooling fan gets screwed in to.)

I have fitted it to both Scott3D's original mount, and einarms' Chimera mount, with no problems.

I have two different sets of these uploaded, one is for the drag chain I used (an Aurarum cable chain available here - www.aurarum.com.au/accessories/674-cable-drag-chain-20x15.html), and the other is a generic blank that you can edit in TinkerCad to add mounting screw holes for your particular drag chain.

Note the pictures are of an earlier version of the design, which used a different cable chain, and an inferior (weaker) frame mount which made cables susceptible to getting cut by sharp extrusion edges, if the drag chain was mounted on the front side (rather than the back as pictured)

Printer:

HyperCube Evolution

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

A high infill is important on the frame side adapter, at least for PLA. Otherwise you might overtorque the securing screw and crack the adapter.

Preparation

You will most likely need to make a small edit to the blank adapter, in order to add screw holes for your particular cable chain. In order to do this:

  1. download the blank adapters
  2. carefully measure where your cable chain's mount holes are
  3. Import each blank adapter's STL into TinkerCad
  4. create some 'hole' cylinders of 3.5mm diameter and place them where they should go on the adapter
  5. select all the parts and group them together
  6. export your TinkerCad project as STL and print away!
Installation

Installation on the gantry side involves:

  1. remove existing part-cooling fan
  2. if the part-cooling fan screwhole isn't straight through, drill it out
  3. press the gantry side adapter in from behind
  4. reinstall the part-cooling fan. You will need a longer M3 screw than last time, I use M3x30
  5. Secure the sandwich with a screw, or (my preference) a wing-nut for easy removal

Installation on the frame side involves:

  1. place on the rear-right corner of the HCEvo frame
  2. secure to frame with a T-nut, like most other bits of the HCEvo

The adapter is meant to cover the entire rear-right corner, including the upright extrusion. That way all the cables exiting don't have the possibility of snagging or getting cut on the edges of your upright extrusion, which may be quite sharp.

Installing the cable chain involves using an M3x10 screw through the drag chain's mounting holes and the adapter, secured with a nut on the other side. I recommend using a Nyloc nut as standard nuts have a tendency to loosen over time with all the vibration it's subjected to.

author: petertee

description.text:
This is a half-box sized to hold a single player cube for the board game Terraforming Mars. This box can be glued to any object so that object can serve as a tile on the game board. Specifically this was designed to be glued on top of a "Nuclear Zone" or "Atomares Sperrgebiet" tile that was posted on the Board Game Geek forums which didn't have a sufficient socket for a player cube. The STL models posted on BGG were extremely high quality and I had trouble editing them in software so I instead designed this part which, if everything is printed in the same color ABS, can be easily glued onto the top of either Nuclear Zone piece using an Acetone/ABS glue.

More details on the parts for this game can be found here https://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/142444/error/expired/3d-printable-stl-terrain-pieces

title: Slim Wallet V4.0 - Bigger / Stronger / Money Holder

description.text:
Redesigned Wallet

This is a work in progress so if you have suggestions then please leave it in the comments so that I can improve this wallet for myself and everyone else!

Issues with the original

  • Case cracking by the lever
  • Hinge was cracking
  • Had to enlarge the hinge holes to allow 1.75 mm filament as a hinge
  • Wall thickness was not optimised for a 0.3 mm nozzle so the cards would not fit and the model had to be scaled to 101%
  • Not able to hold enough cards
  • No money holder

Resolved Issues

Version 4.1

  • Larger hinge so that will not break as easily.
  • I have lowered the quick access card holder which provides more wall support and prevents cracking by the lever. To strengthen the wall on the other side I added a money pocket which of course is useful in itself.
  • Since 0.4 mm nozzles are most popular and I have a 0.3 mm nozzle, I increased the wall thickness to 1.2 mm which would be compatible with both nozzles. This has a benefit of being stronger which was requested by numerous comments on the original design.

Version 4.2

  • Reduced overall thickness thereby scaling card thickness to a lower tolerance
  • Slightly reduced lever thickness and added a 0.2 mm slot to allow it to slide in. Expected 0.2 mm layer height when printing
  • Decreased the tolerance between the lid and the case hinge
  • Reduced filament hinge hole from 2.2 mm to 2.0 mm to better allow for 1.75 mm filament
  • Testing a money clip extending from the money pocket!

Version 4.3

  • Better money clip!

Wallet Remix v34 - 55 mm quick card slot.stl

  • Reduced the overall width of the inside cards by 0.1mm to allow the lid to stay closed
  • Continued with the money slot design where the lid stops the money from falling out

Wallet Remix v36 - 54.3 mm quick card slot.stl

  • Added a version with a smaller quick card slot for those who say that their card falls out

comments.text: My cards fly away when I pull the lever :D
comments.author: vedranius

comments.text: Holy moley, that 4.3 experiment model looks nice!  Have you had a chance to make it yet?
comments.author: Sigismond0

comments.text: No I have been pretty happy with the latest design and have not needed to work on that experimental one. I will have some free time soon so I may work on it then
comments.author: Sigismond0

comments.text: In blatant disregard for the filename, I went ahead and printed it last night to see how it would come out.  I really like the design for the money clip section.  The other ones put stress on a very thin cross-section of layers, but this has a really nice lip that just works.  I will note the same minor issues--the card slot on the back is too loose to actually hold a card and the lid isn't tight enough to actually hold shut.  Nothing a little tape for spacing won't fix, I think.  The lever inside seems to have way too much tolerance, with enough wiggle in it to allow a card to slide behind the lever and jam things up.  It doesn't seem to happen in regular use, but it can happen if you're not careful.
comments.author: Brandon2255p

comments.text:
I just printed the wallet and assembled it. It works amazing! This will defiantly replace my standard wallet. The only problem I had with it is that outside card holder is a little loose. If I would have left a card in the outside it would slide out. I was able to fix this by just pushing down the edges of the pocket to hold the card better. Also, I didn't print the design with the clip because I figured I would just break it. I think the best fix for this would be to just to put a standard money clip on the outside.
I appreciate the file, and can't wait to see the next version!
comments.author: kyleracel

comments.text:
Thanks for the positive feedback! There is a v 4.3 that has a pretty solid money clip on it. Printed it today and just uploaded it.
Its strange that you are having issues with the outside card holder. Mine is quite tight. Glad you managed to solve it though
comments.author: kyleracel

comments.text: I printed it, and it works great! I still have the problem with the outside card slot being loose, but like I said earlier, it is easily fixed with a pair of pliers.
comments.author: Brandon2255p

comments.text: This looks like a great design!  I will have to print one here soon.  Although I do hope you make the money clip a little thicker, it looks to be flimsy.
comments.author: kyleracel

comments.text: Thanks! Please check out the file Experiment_V4.3_do_not_print.stl that I just uploaded and share your thoughts. It is not done yet
comments.author: kyleracel

comments.text: It looks like a cool design.  I would think just a traditional money clip design on that side would work best, but that looks great as well.
comments.author: Brandon2255p

comments.text: 4.2 printed and it works amazing! I have not tested the clip with anything, but it does seem to be a bit thin and I'm concerned about it snapping off if it gets snagged in my pocket. Time will tell. Great work!
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: Please check out the file Experiment_V4.3_do_not_print.stl that I just uploaded. Far from done but that is the concept I am playing with
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: That looks rugged. Like it's ready to go on a jungle safari. What software do you use for your designs?
comments.author: Brandon2255p

comments.text: I use fusion 360 because it's free and amazing
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: I hear that a lot. I've used it a little bit, but OpenSCAD is more my speed.
comments.author: Brandon2255p

comments.text: I am a huge fan of open source and did try out OpenSCAD but the amount of effort you have to put in to yield results similar to fusion 360 or solidworks is huge. I would advise anyone  if you are trying to make anything remotely complex or something that needs to look good then spend the time and learn fusion
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: I get it. Most of what I've designed has been accuracy over complexity or looks. Making frames with specifically sized and placed holes is just easier for me if i  can put numbers in and do math on the spot. Maybe add time goes on I'll have a need for something more like fusion.
comments.author: Brandon2255p

comments.text: Thanks! I agree about the clip. I will be trying your idea of extending it with a finger slider. Mine has not snapped or got snagged in my pocket yet so I am delaying the new design a bit
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: Yeah, the tip of the clip snapped off today in my pocket. I found two little plastic pieces that were the very end of the clip where it curved. It still functions though.
comments.author: Brandon2255p

comments.text: Having printed, and currently using the original Slim Wallet v4.0, I don't understand the problems most people are having? The pin holes in the hinge fit a piece of filament perfectly and I have not had any cracking. Now maybe it's because I'm printing in PETG instead of PLA. I do see a need for it to be slightly larger to hold more cards. I think I will try your design out just to see if it better suites my needs. Thanks for the design!
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: Maybe other peoples printers are not as good or as accurate. I know have a home built Prusa i3 which is definitely not on the quality level of an Ultimaker or Original Prusa. I also printed in PETG. I want to make some minor adjustments to this over the next few days (see the TODO list). But I welcome any feedback before or after the adjustments :)
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: Ok, I printed it at 0.2mm and assembled it. First, the hinge for the lid is too loose. I would say widen the two posts on the body side a hair to take up the slack there. The hinge for the lever is way too tight. The dimples inside I think are the problem. Once it was in (cracked the body a little getting it in place) it was ok, maybe a tad loose. I suggest making the dimples a little shorter or taper the lever to the hole to ease assembly. Other than that, the front card slot and everything seems to fit perfectly. I'll use it for a while and see how it wears. Nice work!
comments.author: Brandon2255p

comments.text: Added your comments to the issues and made a new version. I am much happier with this iteration.
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: Nice! I like that clip too! Another suggestion I came up with today was to extend the pocket on the side higher and put a slot in the middle just wide enough to use a finger to push things out. I'm printing the clip version. The wallet worked great today.
comments.author: Brandon2255p

comments.text: I printed a copy of the original slim wallet at 0.1mm and it definitely was too weak. The one I've been using I printed at 0.3mm and it hasn't had an issue. My printer is just a cheap chinese knock off Prusa i3 that I've heavily modified. I know it's accurate. The 100mm test comes in at ~100.05 on both X and Y and the 50mm test for the Z came in at 49.99mm. Most of the issues I have is with slicing. S3D just hasn't been the same since the version 4 update.
comments.author: Brandon2255p

comments.text: Do you have a 0.4mm nozzle? I still suspect that my 0.3 mm nozzle was the reason I was not able to get my cards in the original design. I use Slic3r and its taken me quite a while to fine tune the settings. But it works so I do not want to for out the cash for Simplify3D.
comments.author: naviathan

comments.text: I do have a 0.4mm nozzle. I don't blame you for not wanting to shell out for simplify, it was worthwhile last year, but Cura and Slic3r have come a long way since then.
comments.author: Brandon2255p

title: Samsung Galaxy Note 3 wall dock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I made this phone dock for myself personally, so it may not fit your needs. My phone has a Spigen Neo Hybrid case on it, so all measurements were done with the case on my phone. So a naked Note 3 will fit in this dock fine, but with a tad bit of slop. You may have to make shims if your not happy with the play. I also included the measurements in the picture, just in case you want to measure your case to see if it will fit in this dock. Sorry if the measurements look confusing, they are for the actual I.D. of the slot where the phone slides into. If your case/phone are equal to or smaller than the measurements, then it should fit. USB cable fitment into the bottom of the phone may vary depending on the thickness of your case at the bottom of your phone. This dock was designed to use the stock Samsung 2.0/3.0 usb cable. I just figured I'd upload this design just in case someone could make use of it besides myself.

print_settings.Notes:: Once you get the settings for the leaves sorted, you can print one after the other like a factory. They took 2 hours each. 12 Leaves.

description.text:
I've been developing algorithms for genetic fractals for the last decade and this project served as a test drive of my new 3D Printer (Creality CR10 Mini).

The 12 leaves are printed separately and inserted in the lamp base.

The lamp base is design to take an E14 fitting which fits directly into the lamp base on a rim inside the base. Refer photo above for the type of fitting. Please see the IMPORTANT notes below.

I used a remote controlled colour E14 led bulb which lights the lamp up beautifully at night. Lots of lovely colours :)

Enjoy.

===================================================================

IMPORTANT: ONLY USE LOW POWER LED LIGHT BULBS IN THIS LAMP!!!
If you use incandescent or other types of lamp you will probably melt the lamp and possibly start a fire.

IMPORTANT: WHEN INSTALLING THE LAMP FITTING, BE CAREFUL WITH THE WIRING. YOU WILL BE PLUGGING THIS INTO A MAINS OUTLET AND NEED TO KNOW THE RISKS OF ELECTRIC SHOCK.
If you have no experience with electricity, then this project is probably not for you.

YOU BUILD THIS LAMP AT YOUR OWN RISK. I TAKE NO RESPONSIBILITY FOR YOUR ACTIONS.

Printer:

Creality

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

There are two parts: the lamp base and the leaves that slot into the base. The settings above are for the base only. Here are more details.

Before anything else: Make sure that you scale the design correctly on your slicer. The base should be 235 mm high. The leaves should be 225 mm between the most distant branches.

The base is a straightforward print. I used 1mm wall thickness to make the base sturdy. In particular the 'feet' need to be strong at the points where they attach to the base. You need to print the supports because otherwise the E14 fitting ring inside the base won't print well enough. This is a 15 hour build.

The leaves are a different story... I made at least 10 partial prints to get these right!

The problem is that the first layer needs to be very well stuck to the build plate. I build on glass with hairspray. Because these leaves have very thin branches (128), if only one of them lifts during the build, the print head will catch it on the next pass and lift the piece from the build plate, completely or partially. Either way, the print will be ruined.

In the end, I added a "rim" to the end of the branches that keep them all together and well stuck. Problem solved. IMPORTANT: When printing the leaves, make sure that the rim touches the bed. Refer to the photo detail above.

But there are still many sharp lines that get put down during the first layer that need to stick well. Things like blobs need to be avoided for the same reason.

On my printer I print the first layer 10 degrees higher: I also SLOW DOWN the print speed for the first layer to a 10mm/s. Believe me, it is worth the extra few minutes.

Once you get the settings for the leaves sorted, you can print one after the other like a factory. They took 2 hours each. 12 Leaves.

Lamp assembly

You need to cut the rim of the leaves to expose the branches. Just cut along the rim as shown on the photo.

If you used the right scaling, than the leaves should fit nicely in the slots in the base. If not, either sand the lips down or thicken them with tape. I don't recommend that you glue the leaves in place since you won't be able to change the LED bulb...

Getting the fitting and LED bulb in place is tricky since you can't get your hands inside the lamp from the top. I screwed the bulb in the fitting first and then lightly taped a short cardboard tube to the bulb which allow me to manipulate it inside the lamp. Not great, but fortunately these LED bulbs tend to last (...!)

The base was designed with Fusion 360.

The leaves are designed with a algorithm that I developed for creating smooth tree fractals, i.e. fractals whose branches have no corners or sharp bends. In this particular example, the fractal was fitted to grow to a semi-circular boundary.

comments.text:
Hi, I like the lamp design but one question: Did you print the base in clear plastic? I presume that the LED bulb is inside the Base?
Thanks
Jack Brinkman
comments.author: jackBrinkman

comments.text: Hi, thanks. It is all printed in white plastic, very opaque in fact. When select colour lighting it just lights up the base. With white light (which uses all three colours) it actually lights the area like a lamp.

My girlfriend's favorite pencil sharpener stopped working, so I opened it up and found a gear broken into several pieces (photo). I checked for printable models online and found nothing, but saw someone was selling 3D printed replacements for $12.50. This made me pretty angry, so I decided to design my own in Tinkercad (with the help of a gear script). The center hole was a little snug printed on a Rep2X in black ABS. You may need to adjust the hole size slightly depending on your printer. Otherwise working great after a few test sharpens. You can edit the tinkercad model here and also not pay $12.50: https://tinkercad.com/things/6nqhKOHp530
Printed in black ABS on a Rep2X using 3 shells, 10% infill, 0.20mm layer height using MakerWare.

comments.text: Awesome! Just got my first printer, and my wife's pencil sharpener just broke with the same problem. I was going to try 3D scanning it, but this is just what I was looking for!
comments.author: humanistical

comments.text: Thank Brian this will be my first model printing, hopefully I can bring to life my old 4 sharpeners. All of them had the same problem!
comments.author: fxv45811

comments.text: This model is not correct. The bore needs to have a completely round hole for 3/4 of the depth and then change to the hole with two flat sides.
comments.author: 69GCBC

comments.text: I'll take a look at it, but it did fit and work on the sharpener I repaired.
comments.author: 69GCBC

comments.text: Thanks Brian. We were able to make it work also but we really had to force it on the shaft because of the interference fit. You have the best design for 3-D printing I've seen so far. If I could edit the .stl file I'd change it myself in Solidworks. Everyone here at work was entertained by the technology involved in repairing an old pencil sharpener (Aerospace Engineers are easily entertained). For what it's worth, the round hole extends down .200" from the hub side.
comments.author: brianwsimms

comments.text: I appreciate that.  Feel free to edit the model in TinkerCad and post a remix!
comments.author: 69GCBC

comments.text: Good idea! I'm new to this, so I didn't even realize I could to that. Thanks Brian!
comments.author: brianwsimms

comments.text: There appears to be a "skew" to the gear teeth. I thought it may have been my printer, but if you look at the image, you can see that the teeth do tilt slightly to the left. Was this purposely designed into this piece, or is this an error?
comments.author: Siggy

comments.text: This is purposefully designed to match the original which has the same skew.
comments.author: Siggy

comments.text: Good to know. Thanks!
comments.author: brianwsimms

comments.text: I printed one and resurrected my ancient pencil sharpener. Thanks!!
comments.author: rainmusic

comments.text: That's great, you're welcome!  Better to repair than throw away...

author: steihauer

description.text:
A few years ago I took up the idea of building my own Hurdy Gurdy. Now I’m not much of a craftsman, so that might be a disadvantage. I am, however, a highly experienced mechanical engineer. My normal field is designing equipment for the high-tech industry, with customers around Europe, Japan and Silicon Valley in the US.

So I thought: why not use the tools of the trade, and create a Hurdy Gurdy using modern rapid prototyping technology: Laser Cutting and 3D printing? Would it be possible to create an instrument that is inexpensive to build, and still sounds well.

After about 4 years of working on it on and off, and 4 iterations, I am happy to say that the result is there. I’ve named it the Nerdy Gurdy, and I’m ready to release it into the wild.

http://www.nerdygurdy.nl

If you have questions or remarks: let me know. Based on your feedback I can further improve the design and manual.

description.text:
This is my first thing,

This is a spy tower designed to be placed on the side of a battlefield to warn the populace of anyone approaching.

Could alternatively be printed smaller as a "pop up camera" in the wilderness or attached to a building as a security cam.

Inspiration came from Dunes Windfarms, Mech warriors/battletech terrain, Dragonball, DBZ, halo and destiny, as well as pretty much every anime for city architecture design and the detailing of some of the starwars, star trak and Warhammer (tau) for the detailing.

If this design infringes on anyone's IP too much get in contact and I'll change the offending material, I dont think it should though as it is quite bland in design and incorporates many sources of inspiration

A quick test to see if your support settings are decent. Tests supports against a simple flat 90 degree angle roof and floor

Creates supports for a 90 degree angle roof that touches the floor of the model so that you can test the quality of the underside of the roof and the top of the floor after you remove the supports.

Tips:

  • If the supports are too hard to remove, lower your support infill and/or increase your Z-Gap/Z-Distance
  • If the roof is drooping or is low quality, increase support infill and/or lower your Z-Gap/Z-Distance
  • If the roof droops in the back, lower your X/Y distance
  • If it isn't too hard to remove, but the quality still isn't good, try printing the support with a roof/floor. I know Cura can do this, I dunno about other slicers

Includes two boxes that are 40L x 20W x 20H in mm
The 1mm variant has a thinner wall, ceiling, and roof then the 3mm, so take your pick. The 3mm is the stronger one so you're less likely likely to break it trying to remove the supports

Take the chance to experiment with your support settings and find what works best for you!
If this helped, please post your printer and support settings in the comments!

description.text:
Basically a regular planetary or epicyclic gear, but with a novel approach in toothshape. The Background is, that regular 3D printer are working much more precisely when using round instead of sharp edges for a tooth shape. Perhaps even the stress distribution in the teeth is improved, due to the similarity to bones. The gear can easily be modified by changing the parameters of teth on the sun or planetary wheel, the tooth width, the height or the number of planets. Right now the planet holes are setup for regular skate bearings. Design is still untested.  
20140309 - Update 1: I noticed some misalignment in the gears, I already fixed that but I wait to upload the next version until I also figured out one misaligned polygon in the turning point between tooth valley and top.  
20140309 - Update 2: Okay, the new model is online. Now I fixed the polygon the quick and dirty way. Please make suggestions if you know how to tackle this issue other than adding 0.01mm to the tooth radius.  
20140311 - Update 3: after failing to compile in a sufficient resolution as it is (tens of gigabytes of RAM and hours of compile time later...) I am now working on a solution of getting the job done by first generating dxf files and extruding those in 3D. Compiling separate gears also didn't work.  
20140313 - Update 4: finally, it compiles using about 130min and 5GB of RAM. Saving as stl takes also quite a while.  
20140315 - Update 5: noticed and fixed a bug in calculation of planet rotation for placement, in the center hole calculation as well as a necessary change in orientation when changing the number of planets.  
20140317 - Update 6: okay, so I built it. Unfortunately, the tolerance of 0.4 was quite perfect for the distance between the planets and the annular gear, but too much for the sun gear. Further work needs to be done.  
20140530 - Update 7: I tried to work with the cutting edge offset function of the experimental openscad build, but it seems the tolerance hast to be calculated in dependance of the gear radius. Further investigation is needed. I also thought about printing the gears one at a time, since otherwise they for sure won't make a perfect fit.

To compile just run create.sh. First it generates .dxf files which will later be extruded and saved as .stl. The parameters are mainly stored in wobblegear.scad which also provides the 2D gear function. Printable without support. Right now the sun center hole is dimensioned for a M5 nuts/counternut/bolt, the planets for eight regular skate bearings with 22x7.7mm, 5mm distance piece. The image only shows the 2D view of the gears without holes, because it takes a looong time to render. Right now, it's setup with 20:40:100 teeth, so if the annular wheel is fixed we have a 6:1 ratio. Please note the following:
-gear radius is calculated via teeth dimension and quantity
-changing the teeth quantity/dimension may result in the need to adjusting gear alignments in multiples of alpha.
-right now I am testing with tolerance increased to 0.4 because 0.2 was too less.

……………………

Please see our popular binary titanium key carabiners made from pure titanium, with the safety cage to keep your keys secure, and the built-in bottle opener.

Our other thingiverse projects.

Enjoy

……………………

FAQs from our survey (300+ responses, thanks)

Make it in silicone: tbd, we need something solid, the winning material now is a compound commonly used in production of kitchen cutting boards: strong, survives heat of a dishwasher, FDA approved.

Make it in stainless: yes, after we reach break-even volumes in nylon.

Cup size: my personal hell, with so many definitions of the cup. Good news: the difference between the “legal” and the “customary” US cup is around 1%, so whatever we choose it shouldn’t make a big difference.

Larger cubes (I assume starting at 2 cups): sure, after we take care of the regular and the mini version.

Europe: yes, we’ll be shipping there.

Canada: Qui, bien sûr.

MiniCube: After it’s big brother.

Volume Discounts: We'll offer discounts for 2, 3, 5 cubes… with the shipping cost of multiple cubes close to the cost of shipping of a single cube.

Specs: Dishwasher safe, holds liquids, food grade, FDA safe, BPA-free... Yes, we'll work with the manufacturer to select the correct plastic injection material for food contact application.

Emails in the survey: we'll use them exclusively to let you know when the campaign is ready.

……………………

The Measurement Cube is protected by US patent pending.

comments.text:
PLA is quite safe, it is used as self decaying support in surgery. It can also be eaten without any side effects, it decomposes into lactic acid.
However, any coloring added is most likely be toxic. Additionally, 3D printing process might introduce bits and pieces from your nozzle or extruder assembly. Finally, 3D printed materials have micropores in which bacteria can thrive. Unless you coat 3D printed parts with food safe paint and/or coating, it is not food safe.
TLDR: No 3D printed item is food safe unless you have a specially designed 3D printer for this purpose, regardless of FDA approval.

comments.text: ...and that every step from resin to packaging to extruding to final use and every item that touches it along the way is food-safe as well.  Granted, if you use this only as a dry measuring device, you're not likely to have a problem, but an FDM part, even with 100% infill, will be porous and can be easily and permanently contaminated when using liquids of any type.  So it's not the plastic you have to worry about, for the most part, since contact with foodstuff will be brief.  It's the foodstuff that contacts the plastic during use and remains behind that is problematic.
comments.author: bbendes

comments.text: Indeed, I have so far only once been able to print a tiny container that could hold water without leaking. It was printed with PETG with deliberate over-extrusion. When I used the same settings for a bigger container of the same design, it again leaked. Prints always have tiny gaps and holes even if you cannot see them. Any 3D printed container that should hold a liquid, must be coated on the inside, and if the liquid is for consumption, then obviously that coating must be food-safe. And if it is going to be coated anyway, it matters much less whether the filament itself is perfectly food-safe or not, as long as it doesn't contain chemicals that could leach through the coating into the food.

comments.text: Is there some sort of food safe coating I could put on this (spray, preferably) to make it usable for liquids?
comments.author: The_Batter

comments.text: Paraffin wax might be an idea..  If you want to make sure it's food safe, purchase the type used in sealing home canned food from a grocery store.  It's not spray, it doesn't even come in a liquid form, but it is fairly easy to melt.  You might have to experiment with this to make sure that the volumes in the print are correct post wax processing.
comments.author: The_Batter

comments.text: This is a great idea, but you may want to try a natural beeswax, which we eat in many food products, instead of a paraffin, which is a petroleum-based product.
comments.author: Anathae

comments.text: You could print it in natural PETG if you want to make it foodsafe but it might be hard to read the devisions. PLA isn't going to hurt you though especially since you will be keeping the liquid in it for approximately 10 seconds.
comments.author: The_Batter

comments.text: Agreed, PETG is food safe but you typically need to print your layers a little thicker .2mm at least
comments.author: davwilso

title: Bare LCD / LED display panel stand

description.text:
This is simple stand for bare 14 inch lcd panel and protective case for display driver board, CCFL2, and OSD.

My driver board is RTD2668 based board with CCFL2 standard board.

It might fit your driver board but, double check it before print files

Printer:

moment s

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Stand might be big for your printer. Be mindful on your printer's max volume

Bill of Material

1 x Lcd panel or led panel (Any panel available form you, mine is LP140WX1 )
link : https://www.ebay.com/itm/NEW-14-0-WXGA-LAPTOP-LCD-SCREEN-FOR-LP140WX1-TL-01/361271061943?hash=item541d6eedb7:g:WO4AAOSwPgxVLqKW

1 x Display driver board & OSD & LVDS cable (Make sure you got right firmware for your panel )
link : https://www.ebay.com/itm/8inch-Lattepanda-Raspberry-LCD-Display-Monitor-HDMI-VGA-AV-Control-Driver-Board/192374632131?hash=item2cca6beec3:g:npcAAOSwfVhaFSxC

1 x CCFL2 inverter ( Double check what type of ccfl your panel use )
link :https://www.ebay.com/itm/CCFL-2-Lamp-Universal-Inverter-board-Input-Voltage-10-28V-for-15-22-inch-Monitor/322200610507?hash=item4b04a726cb:g:bEkAAOSwdzVXkZLl
1 x Double side tape
link : https://www.ebay.com/itm/2x-3M-Roll-Automotive-Acrylic-Double-Sided-Tape-1-4-5-16-7-16-1-2-1-1-5-2/401376741117?hash=item5d73eb06fd:m:m-dL3hLpVHICZLyRdjov_vw

1 x Xiaomi Mi Power Bank 2
link : https://www.ebay.com/itm/10000mAh-Xiaomi-Mi-Power-Bank-2-Quick-Charge-External-Battery-Android-IOS-F1Y6/362145029116?epid=8008269885&hash=item5451869bfc:m:m4ewQOwHYmGNpkpt1SCx2Hw

1 x XL6009 Boost converter ( Setting it to 9-12v )
link : https://www.ebay.com/itm/DC-DC-Adjustable-Step-up-boost-Power-Converter-Module-XL6009-Replace-LM2577-Pop/232573859959?epid=1364500465&hash=item36267b7877:g:mxsAAOSwnANZ4Hrq

1 x usb cable
link :https://www.ebay.com/itm/Black-PowerLine-Micro-USB-Charging-Cable-4ft-for-Samsung-Android-Smartphones/132415939793?hash=item1ed49ae4d1:g:F-gAAOSwdW9Z8t1T

EXTRA :

x Set of printed parts ( stand, adboard, osd, ccfl2 )
x Some M3 bolts and nuts for securing parts

Assembly
  1. Check you LCD/LED panel working before proceed to next step
  2. Open up USB cable and solder power cables to boost converter input
  3. Connect boost converter output ( set output to 9-12v ) to driver board
  4. Plug USB cable and check driver board powered up well or not
  5. Use tape or bolts to secure boards to printed cases and Secure boost converter back of driver board case with bolts & nuts
  6. Tape CCFL inverter to LCD panel
  7. Tape stand to power bank ( Make sure it support panel without problem )
  8. Connect driver board, OSD & CCFL board, and display together
  9. Check display works well and configure it to your best setting
Trouble Shooting
  1. It use about 15 watt so, you must power display from power bank or USB 3.0 port
    2 Check XL6009 's temperature. it will hot after several hours

description.text: Filament guiding system for CR10s that includes the filament detector what is delivered with the machine. All parts have been printed in PLA with standard setting for the printer and worked fine.

Printer:

Creality3D CR10s

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,15

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed in PLA with 215 C°
Printbed 50 C°

Print the wheel 2 times and make one of them (white in the picture) clean and smooth on the inside to let it move easily on the axis. Use the second one (black in the picture) to fix the first one on the axis. Clean the holes in the plate before mounting it to the printer. To place the detector into position I have cut all overhangs of the box of the detector.
(As I had not enough space to the housing I have bowed the plate a little bit.)

The plate can be mounted to the baseplate of the filament drive with the 2 existing screws.
This version has no mounting cutout for the z-axis-spindle (just the hole) but you can cut this out with a cutter very easily if you do not want to disassemble the spindle.

After I have made a housing for my CR10s I had to find a solution for the filament feeding inside the housing. As the filament feed drive moves with the x-axis up and down, depending on the hight of the print, the guide had to move with it. I included the filament detector into the simple design.

title: P3Steel - Y-axis idler Ø5mm bearings & 20 theeth GT2 Pulley
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was in need to replace my weared off 3D-printed idler pulleys, the ones i got for replacement have Ø5mm bearings and are a bit wide for Toolson's idler so I've remixed it.

First of all, I've widened the pulley receptacle to accomodate ≈10mm wide pulleys.

I've made recesses (2mm deep) for the nut and screw allowing the use of a M5 x 20mm screw.

Also, I've aded a connection from the base to the support structures in the back to improve their adhession to the bed.

If you think it deserves downloading... Please leave a Like!

remixed_from.author: pokeimon
remixed_from.title: TS100 Iron Solder Box and tip holder

title: TS100 Soldering Iron Box with Tip Holders
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A fully refactored version of the original box, requiring less material to print, with included spare screw holders.

The soldering iron clamp is removable, so when and if it breaks, you don't have to print the whole case.

Change Log

Update 2017-12-09
  • The grip of the front clips on the top cover is slightly decreased, because the tips are 0.2 mm wider on the front than on the back. It makes the tips easier to remove and insert, and the clips are less likely to break.
Update 2017-12-04
  • The box now requires two pieces of 1.75 mm filament for hinges, instead of 2 mm nails. Cut out two 24 mm long pieces of the filament, and insert one in each hinge.
Update 2017-12-01 - Major Safety Fix
  • Top lid is now flipped, and tip clips are shortened by 1mm, so the tips would not come in contact with the soldering iron case under any circumstances.

There has been reported one case with the previous version that the tips on the top lid broke the LCD screen when the box closed. Even though it may work fine for you (as it currently does for me), the fact is that under certain circumstances that indeed could have happened. Therefore I flipped the top lid, and shortened the tip clips to additionally increase the distance between the tips and the soldering iron.

If you already have printed the older version I strongly advise to replace the top lid with this new version.

Update 2017-11-30
  • Some printers are unable to reproduce sharp edges, such as on the bottom of the clamps, so they end up being too loose for the groove on the bottom part of the box. So I made an upgraded version of the bottom part, with trails that provide extra grip for the clamps.

If you already have printed the old version of the bottom part, and you find your clamp being too loose, you can either try to print a clamp in a vertical (standing-up) position, or you can just glue your clamp to the base.

What's New
  • Refactored from the scratch
  • Thinner sides (requiring less material to print)
  • Added 2 spare screw holders
  • The top and the bottom part are of the same height
  • Using 2 pieces of 24 mm long 1.75 mm filament for the hinges
  • Additional TS100 soldering iron and soldering tip models for virtual testing in the design phase

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.30

Infill:

90%

Notes:
  • Perimeters: 3 (to ensure that the hinges don't break)
  • Infill: 90% (infill is used just on a very few parts, so it does not affect the overall material consumption, but on the hinges it is critical to be as solid as possible)
  • Material: ABS

comments.text: I'm keeping a very keen eye on this project! The previous remix (by pokeimon) was very close to being perfect, but the tolerances were slightly off so the hinges broke and the spare tip clips broke as well (when I printed it in PLA, at least). I tried tweaking that design myself, but I'm really not any good at modifying meshes. Once this remix has had a few more tweaks (especially looking forward to the idea of using filament for the hinges!) I'll have another go at printing it - either in ABS or PETG.

title: RF100 heavy spool hub adapter thing

description.text:
Helps a large filament spool (with a 53mm central hole, 60mm deep) spin smoothly on the RF100 standard spool holder.

  • A 1kg filament spool I have has a rough spindle hole and was snagging once every revolution, producing regular skipped extrusion/weak layers/horribleness in my prints.

Outer diameter is 50mm, inner is 36mm, and it is 70mm long (slips easily and securely over the standard RF100 spool holder pin). The flange is 60mm diameter and 5mm deep, allowing for a spool hub width up to 65mm. It was designed with a specific spool in mind, but should work with many others.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/c7F1nUFlQYJ

description.text:
When I am designing something in 3d, I always have the problem to visualize the thickness of the perimeters of my models. This is why I decided to design and share this simple tool to help me and others who have the same problem.

Measurements of thickness can also be done by checking the difference in high between 2 adjacent steps for example the 3 mm step that is not present by default can be calculated/visualized as the difference in height between the 7.0 and 4.0 steps.

This tool can also be used to check the accuracy of the printer, each square is designed to be 10mm x 10mm and the text is 0.4 mm thickness with a height of 5 mm.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15 %

Notes:

The steps are in multiples of 0.2 mm, just because the printing resolution that I choose was 0.2 mm.

Total print size 50mm x 50mm with a maximum height of 30.4 mm.

My estimated print time is about 1.5 - 2 h. (highly dependent on the settings and printer)

description.text:
Created to store my API brand water test kits for use with my aquariums, aquaponics garden setup and koi tank !

Displays 5 test kit colour charts & holds 10 test tubes (with or without cap on base) & has space for up to 10 test kit bottles.

I am not affiliated with API !

Based on https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1656361

Following user request - updated to hold 2 test tubes per chart

Printer:

Yasin 200 Dual Extruder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I printed in Yasin Grey PLA (1.75mm).
Print the Tray Handle oriented vertically, with the star shape on the print bed.
I did not need raft.

Slide the Tray Handle into the bottom of the Tray Base until flush. It is intended as an interference fit, and slid together well on my print, and is retained well (but can be easily popped back out). You may need to trim if your print tolerances are larger than mine (!)

Having had all the test kit bits in a plastic box under the bench and fed up with where to put the test tubes during a test, I designed this holder to house all the API kits I have.
Whilst it is good for storage, it is also designed to be useful during a test to hold the test tubes and have the colour chart right there when needed.
Designed this in Solidworks.
If you want the source file to create a remix - or as a recent user did - request an update (hence this post) then please drop me a line

This thing provides support for a 20mm spindle (https://www.directplastics.co.uk/acetal-rod) on which filament spools can be hung.

Attachment thru the feet is made using M3 bolts which connect to M3 flanged rivnuts (sometimes referred to as nutserts). These rivnuts are push fitted into 3D printed stands.

http://www.ukfixings.net/M3-x-10.9mm-Flange-Head-Rivet-Nuts-Knurled-Body-Box-of-100.html

2x stands and optionally 1x centre are used to support the spindle. A 19mm rod of length determined by the user to provide the spindle.

Optionally 623ZZ Miniature Ball Bearing 3mm x 10mm x 4mm can be pushed into the eds supports (https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B014IF8M34). These allow the centres of the 19mm spindle to be accurately drilled using a 3mm twist drill.

The 19mm Rod Jig also accepts push fitted 623ZZ bearings, allowing mounting holes to be drilled accurately in the supporting platform. Note this jig is not required for the support.

description.text:
I wanted to print the Caveira emblem of the famous game Rainbow Six Siege.

I saw that Ruben472 made other R6S Operator emblems so I asked him if he could make also the cav one. After some days he published it and I tried to print but I had some problems.
The design had lot of very thin section (specially the scars on the mouth) that the original 0.4mm extruder nozzle of my Anet A6 could not reproduce.

So I modified a little the file in order to make them thicker enough to be printed without any problems.

Since I have white and black PLA I decided to print the emblem in two colors but printing just a single file.
I designed it in 2 parts of 2mm height. I set the layer's height to 0.2mm so I had to print 10 layers per color. The base/background was printed in white PLA and the remaining part of the emblem was printed in black PLA (in this way I also avoided to use any glue to attach the pieces together).

P.S. Since I didn't have any green filament I decided simply to cut a piece of green paper to the right shape.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

print 10 layers in White PLA

pause print
swap filament
extrude the white residues
resume print

print 10 layers in Black PLA

(paint the green section by hand)

description.text:
This is a hanging Stevenson Screen for an Oregon Scientific outdoor wireless weather station. It's designed to hang from a tree or pole. I've added a link to the CAD document so you can customise the base for different sized weather station modules. It is completely 3D printed, no other hardware needed.

You'll need to print a base and top and however many connectors and middles you need (I needed 5 middles and 18 connectors).

You can prise the top off to access the weather station module to change batteries etc.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 layer height

Infill:

30%

Notes:

You need to flip the middle upside down before printing and turn the connector 90 degrees so it lies on one of its flat sides.

Printed with white PETG from Extrudr. Their PETG prints at quite a low temperature and is super strong along the filament direction. I basically use their filament for everything as it is a lot stronger than PLA and doesn't smell when you are printing it.

Printed at 220C with 80C bed. Straight on to cleaned PEI bed, remove when still warm, spraying with alcohol or isopropanol helps release the print.

Hi!

This is a rework of an old Arduino project.

Basically it's a set of pieces that works as a stand for a protoboard and some components that i've used to made a Tetris Machine.

In the pictures i´m using my DIY Controller but you can build your own using a PS2-like joystick and 3 buttons

Included the .ino file. It uses the Fastled, LedControl and Adafruit_TicoServo libraries (downloadable from the library manager of the IDE)

Component list:

  • Arduino Uno/Nano
  • Servo (a cheap SG90 it's ok)
  • Two 8x8 RGB Matrix (using cheap chinese matrix found in ebay)
  • Display MAX7219
  • PS2-like joystick
  • 3 switch buttons

PINOUT for the Arduino:

  • Joystick
  • AX --> A0
  • AY --> A1
  • Buttons
  • Rotate CW -->D3
  • Rotate CCW -->D4
  • Start -->D5
  • RGBMatrix --> D8
  • Servo-->D9
  • Display Max7219
  • Data -->D10
  • CS -->D11
  • CLK -->D12

Important Tip: Don't feed the RGB Matrix trough the Arduino, the two matrix together can consume more than 1Amp and you the Arduino can't manage such high currents.

There's two versions for the Matrix diffusor in one or two pieces. If you can manage filament changes i recommend print the 'matrix_cover_with_diffusor.stl' and change from white to a dark color fillament when starting to print the grid. The white panel has a 0.6mm thickness. You can also print the white panel and the grid separated then stick them with glue or tape but works better when printed in one piece.

See below for some useful pics and more instructions/tips.

See in action (an earlier prototype) in this video: https://youtu.be/qHTFjGCErSI

Enjoy this nice weekend projet and have fun!!
Components used 8x8 RGB Matrix (x2) SG90 Servo MAX7219 display Joystick + buttons Arduino NANO Protoboard power adapter

Two RGB Matrix Connect the two matrix Use grid + diffusor over the matrix, use tape for fix the matrix grid+diffusor Printing grid+diffusor in one piece...changing filament Display and front panel Insert the display in front panel Put the cover Insert the servo into dial, you may need a bit of sanding Insert the dial in top part Replace the Servo Stick with the 'next' piece. When the game is over (pieces falling down) it must be pointing at 90º (vertical) Feed the matrix (ant other components) from the power source, NOT trough the arduino Feeding the NANO board Put some order in this mess!!!
Typical values for SG90 Servos. If your servo doesn't point properly to the pieces, change this.

author: massimorocca

description.text:
Requires minor use of soldering iron.
Re-Use is the best form of re-cycling.

Need a USB cable (any unused USB cable as shown in photo).
Need a USB mains plug (any unused USB mains plug).
Need a high output LED (I got mine by buying a front cycle lamp from PoundLand, took it apart, got 5 LEDs).
Need a 1K Ohm resistor (maplin, Farnell or such).
Take the USB cable, cut off the end that does NOT plug into main plug. Strip it back, keeping just the red and black wires, strip them back for connecting (see photo).
Solder the resistor to the +ve contact of the LED.
Solder the black wire to the -ve contact of the LED.
Solder the red wire to the other end of the resistor.
(see photo).
Plug into main socket, plug socket into main, should light (see photo).
Wrap exposed wiring with electrical tape. (see photo)
Print NightLightBase.stl (I used 3 vertical shell perimeters, 3 horizontal perimeters, 1.0 Fill Density, PLA or ABS, any colour, I used white PLA and clear ABS at different times, material really doesn't matter).
Print NightLightStem.stl (same settings as base).
Screw stem into base, thread cable through, you can now plug in to check working.
See pictures for sequential series showing base assembly and wire threading.
Print either NightLightMoon.stl, NightLightMickey.stl or NightLightShStar.stl. I used same shells but 0.2 Fill Density, Clear ABS, gives nice translucent shade. This diffuses the LED nicely.
Slide shade down over stem, Job done. Running cost:
In use, the light takes less than 1 milli Amp (1 thousandth of an Amp) or less than 5 milli Watts. Virtually free to run, no batteries.
Leaving 60 watt light on, (even with ballast dimmer it still takes 60 watt). This saves a fortune. Making cost:
Base, stem and upport together weigh 91g, shooting star shade weighs 80g. I bought 1KG Clear ABS plastic off fourstar168 on Ebay for ÃÂ£19.99.
(91+80)/1000*19.99=ÃÂ£3.42 for plastic. The rest was lying around my house unused or needed. Though you can buy the plug and cable together on Ebay for less than ÃÂ£2. Making time:
Assembly takes me about 10 minutes.
Base and stem I can comfortably to in 1 evening including clean up. Shade takes another evening. Though of course, this is mainly printer running, me doing something else. Let's face it, if you can attach a jpeg to Thingiverse then this is dead easy.

author: FernandoF

description.text:
Recently we discovered that our 2017 Honda CR-V has a hidden feature which lets you roll down all the windows and open the sunroof using your key fob remote. Sounds good, right? Well what if the car is parked outside in the rain and you bump the button while going about your business indoors? We had this happen, although minus the rain, luckily. The windows were open all night.

Since the feature can't be disabled, I created this key fob cover to prevent it from happening again. The fob slides in and stays put due to a snug fit. Since this is a keyless entry / keyless start vehicle, you don't normally need access to the buttons, you just leave the fob in your pocket. If you do want to use the buttons, you can use the lock button while the fob is in the case, but for others you'll need to slide it out of the case -- that's the whole point of it.

Print in the orientation shown. The arch seems to print okay without supports, but adding supports improved the quality slightly for me.
